{{der-top|Compounds}}
* {{ja-r|誕%生%寺|^たん%じょう%-じ}}: Tanjō-ji, Tanjō Temple: any of various Buddhist [[temple]]s or places in Japan
* {{ja-r|寺%域|じ%いき}}: the [[grounds]] of a [[temple]]
* {{ja-r|寺%印|じ%いん}}: the [[official]] [[stamp]] or [[seal]] of a Buddhist [[temple]]
* {{ja-r|寺%院|じ%いん}}: a Buddhist [[temple]]
* {{ja-r|寺%社|じ%しゃ}}: [[temple]]s and [[shrine]]s
{{der-bottom}}

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|てら}}

From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=てら|-}}.  Found in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'', completed some time after 759 CE.<ref>{{RQ:Manyoshu|16|3822}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man16Yo.html#3822 here]</ref>

There are various theories regarding the ultimate derivation.
* Some sources<ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref> derive Japanese ''tera'' from Middle {{der|ja|ko|sort=てら|졀}}. This is from earlier {{m|ko|뎔||[[temple]]}} and is the nativised reading of {{ko-l|찰|刹|Buddhist temple}} below, deriving in turn from {{cog|ltc|-}} {{ltc-l|剎}}, shortened from {{ltc-l|剎多羅|[[Buddhist]] [[monastery]], [[temple]] or [[shrine]]}}, borrowed from {{cog|sa|क्षेत्र||[[land]], [[area]], [[domain]]}}.
* Other sources<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> describe Japanese ''tera'' as cognate with modern {{cog|ko|-}} {{ko-l|찰|刹|temple}}, appearing as a component in terms such as {{ko-l|선찰|禪刹|Zen temple}}, {{ko-l|사찰|寺刹|Buddhist temple}}.
* Another derivation<ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref><ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> is given as {{der|ja|pi|sort=てら|thera||[[elder]]s}} in reference to the monks.

Considering the phonetic development in Korean, the avenues for transmission of Buddhist terms to Japan, and the consistent {{m|en|temple}} sense of the Japanese term throughout recorded history, the now-obsolete {{cog|ko|뎔||temple}} may be a more likely source than {{cog|pi|thera||elders}}.
